questions.question: Match method characteristics: ICP maintained first circulation; Usually lower annulus pressures; Kill mud pumped with influx; Influx circulated before kill mud
questions.explanation: Driller's: circulate out kick first (ICP maintained), then pump kill mud (influx already out). W&W: kill mud follows kick up annulus (together), reducing annular pressures.

questions.question: Kill startup statements? (SELECT TWO)

options.A: Maintain constant DP pressure when bringing pump to kill speed
options.B: Surface line volume affects when kill mud increases hydrostatic
options.C: Bring pump to speed holding casing pressure constant
options.D: Surface line volume not needed consideration

questions.explanation: Hold CASING constant during startup (C)—this maintains BHP. Surface line volume delays kill mud reaching DS (B). DP pressure changes during startup; don't try to hold it.

questions.question: Gas influx circulation - pit volume trend?
questions.explanation: Gas expands as it rises. Expansion pushes mud out. Pit volume increases, sometimes dramatically as gas reaches surface.

questions.question: Kill mud reaches rig floor 100 strokes after pumps. W&W adjustment?
questions.explanation: The 100 strokes in surface lines don't add hydrostatic to the well. Re-zero when kill mud enters DS so stepdown chart matches actual DS fill.

questions.question: Best kill technique for long open section?
questions.explanation: Long open hole = more exposure to shoe pressure during gas passage. W&W gets kill mud behind gas, reducing maximum shoe pressure. Driller's has peak pressure later in circulation.

questions.question: Driller's Method: Original SIDPP 750, SICP 1000. After first circ: SIDPP 750, SICP 850. Action?

options.A: Continue second circulation using Wait and Weight stepdown
options.C: Continue second circulation; hold casing constant until kill mud at bit

questions.explanation: SIDPP unchanged (750) confirms formation pressure balanced. SICP dropped (some influx out or compressed). Proceed with W&W stepdown for second circulation—most controlled approach.

questions.question: Driller's Method: Casing pressure while pumping kill mud down drillstring?
questions.explanation: Kill mud in DS only—annulus unchanged. Casing pressure maintains BHP against same annular column. Pressure stays constant until kill mud enters annulus.

questions.question: Choke adjustment - how long for DP response?
questions.explanation: Pressure wave travels ~1000 ft/sec in mud. 10,000 ft well = ~10 second delay. Don't over-adjust waiting for response.

questions.question: When is FCP maintained?
questions.explanation: FCP = Final Circulating Pressure, maintained after kill mud passes bit. DP pressure constant at FCP for rest of circulation. Before bit: follow stepdown schedule.

questions.question: Kick taken 30 stands off bottom. Both pressures 150 psi. Action to restore control?

options.A: Strip to bottom; circulate using Driller's Method
options.B: Circulate while 30 stands off using Driller's Method
options.C: Raise MW 150 psi; circulate using Wait and Weight

questions.explanation: Can't kill effectively off-bottom—kick below bit. Strip pipe to bottom (monitoring pressures), then circulate with proper method. Kill mud needs full circulation path.

questions.question: Correct stripping action?

options.A: Strip until casing = MAASP; bleed each stand
options.C: Bleed DP closed-end displacement each stand
options.D: Bleed DP metal displacement each stand

questions.explanation: Closed-end displacement = volume of steel entering well. Bleed this volume to maintain constant BHP. Open-end (capacity) would over-bleed; metal displacement is a component, not total.

questions.question: Swab kick - is original mud weight sufficient?
questions.explanation: Swab kick occurred because BHP temporarily dropped during trip, not because MW was insufficient. Original MW was maintaining balance—just circulate out the influx.

questions.question: When does Wait & Weight give lower shoe pressure than Driller's?

options.A: When DP capacity less than open hole (minus kick)
options.B: When DP capacity greater than open hole (minus kick)
options.C: Always lower with Wait and Weight

questions.explanation: W&W advantage: kill mud behind gas. If DS capacity < open hole below shoe, kill mud reaches shoe BEFORE gas does. This gives W&W its advantage. Otherwise, benefit diminishes.

questions.question: If gas expansion prevented, effect on BHP?
questions.explanation: Preventing expansion maintains gas at high pressure (small volume). As gas rises, that high pressure adds to surface—BHP would increase. That's why we allow controlled expansion.

questions.question: Horizontal well - why little difference between SIDPP and SICP?

options.B: Same fluid density in horizontal drilling
options.D: Influx vertical height minimal effect on annular hydrostatic

questions.explanation: Horizontal influx has minimal vertical height. Hydrostatic difference between mud and influx depends on VERTICAL height. Horizontal = little height = little SICP difference from SIDPP.

questions.question: Kill mud pump-down in high-angle well. Standpipe pressure compared to vertical?
questions.explanation: High-angle well: kill mud in DS increases DS hydrostatic, but this is offset by less TVD. Net effect: less pressure required than vertical well of same MD.

questions.question: Stripping with float. 93 ft stand, 0.0346 bbl/ft capacity, 0.0438 bbl/ft CE displacement, 0.0092 bbl/ft metal. Bleed volume per stand? Pipe fill volume?
questions.explanation: Bleed = CE displacement × length = 0.0438 × 93 = 4.07 bbl. Fill (with float) = capacity × length = 0.0346 × 93 = 3.22 bbl

questions.question: Volumetric method - when is casing shoe pressure maximum? (SELECT TWO)
questions.explanation: Shoe pressure highest when: gas at shoe (B) - maximum gas height above shoe, and at initial shut-in (C) before any expansion relief. BOP arrival has no shoe significance.

questions.question: Gas migrating, can't start pumps. Which pressure to hold?
questions.explanation: SIDPP directly reflects BHP through clean mud column. Maintain SIDPP constant by bleeding casing (volumetric). SICP affected by influx position; shoe pressure not directly monitored.

questions.question: Stripping to bottom - what volume to bleed?

options.B: Volume = DP closed-end displacement of pipe stripped
options.C: Volume = DP metal displacement of pipe stripped

questions.explanation: Closed-end displacement = steel volume entering hole. Bleed this to maintain constant BHP. Metal displacement is subset; hydrostatic method is volumetric, not stripping.

questions.question: Strip back 6000 ft to 9000 ft, shoe at 6000 ft, 11.4 ppg. Bleed volume? BHP effect if too much/little bled? Casing pressure trend?
questions.explanation: Calculate displacement for 3000 ft. Over-bleed = lose hydrostatic. Under-bleed = trap pressure. Casing increases as pipe withdrawn compresses influx.

questions.question: 1 bbl gas swabbed at 2000 ft. 10 ppg mud. Volume at surface?
Pump to kill rate, DP reads 200 psi above calculated ICP. Action?

options.A: Open choke to reduce DP pressure

questions.explanation: 200 psi above ICP indicates either: wrong SCR value, calculation error, or changed conditions. Recalculate before proceeding.

questions.question: Driller's vs. Wait & Weight comparison?

options.B: Wait & Weight reduces formation breakdown risk

questions.explanation: W&W puts kill mud in drillstring first, reducing maximum annular pressure during kill. This protects weak formations.

questions.question: Vertical well, second circulation of Driller's Method. When does casing pressure decrease?

options.A: Kill mud halfway down drill string

questions.explanation: Casing pressure decreases when HEAVIER fluid enters the annulus. Kill mud enters annulus at the bit.

questions.question: Driller's Method first circulation. Casing pressure while pumping kill mud to bit?
questions.explanation: First circulation uses ORIGINAL mud weight. Annular content unchanged. Casing pressure stays constant.
